intro: Tetramolopium consanguineum subsp. consanguineum, commonly known as the red mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees. It is characterized by its evergreen foliage and produces small, red berries that are an important food source for birds. The plant has a complex life cycle involving both seed dispersal and vegetative propagation. It is native to parts of Australia and is often found in coastal and semi-arid regions. Its botanical features include opposite leaves and a woody stem, which contribute to its ability to survive in diverse environmental conditions.
